title: How to Make Mustard from Scratch

steps.headline: Use utensils and mixing vessels that are glass, or ceramic -- anything but aluminum, which can be dissolved by the vinegar.
Purchase some mustard seed, or ground mustard powder.
steps.description: Whole seeds come in 'white' (yellow), brown, and black varieties. The darker the seed, the stronger the mustard.

steps.headline: Soak the seed for two hours before grinding.
steps.description: Do not try to hurry the process by boiling, as the heat will activate an enzyme that takes away the flavor of mustard.

steps.headline: Grind the mustard seed if it is not already ground.
steps.description: You can use a mortar and pestle if you have one, or a cleaned-out coffee grinder, or even a blender. The sound of the grinding will change when the mustard reaches an evenly ground consistency.

steps.headline: Pour the mustard into a dish and mix with liquid until it is about the consistency of a thick ketchup.
steps.description: For a quick, hot mustard that you will use right away, use water; otherwise use wine/beer/mead, vinegar, or grape juice. Feel free to combine liquids.

steps.headline: Add any desired sweeteners, such as honey, sugar, artificial sweetener, ground dates or raisins, to taste.
Add ground spices.
steps.description: To make it sweeter, try anise or cinnamon; to make it hotter, try ginger, cloves, horseradish (as is the norm in Europe), or one of the black peppers. Taste and adjust seasoning.

steps.headline: Mix together, cover, and leave on the counter until the hotness is at your desired strength.
steps.description: Heat and bitterness will reach a peak in 5-15 minutes; water-based mustard should be served then. For other kinds of mustard, wait between 2 hours and a day for flavors to blend. Aging for a day is typically needed for the flavors to mellow, however some find that the best flavor arises after aging for several weeks. Aging mustard in the refrigerator will cause it to stay hotter longer. Aging mustard in a closed container in a cupboard or on the counter is generally considered safe, as mustard has anti-bacterial properties.

steps.headline: Adjust consistency as necessary with juice, vinegar, or other liquids; mustard will thicken over time.
Take the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Grind in a spice grinder until relatively fine. This way you won't have to do any soaking.

steps.headline: Add the liquid ingredients to a glass bowl.
Add the dry to the liquid and mix  well with a fork.
Mix well with a stick blender until creamy.
Let the mixture rest.
steps.description: It will thicken as it cools.

text: Steps Use utensils and mixing vessels that are glass, or ceramic -- anything but aluminum, which can be dissolved by the vinegar.  Purchase some mustard seed, or ground mustard powder. Whole seeds come in 'white' (yellow), brown, and black varieties. The darker the seed, the stronger the mustard. Soak the seed for two hours before grinding. Do not try to hurry the process by boiling, as the heat will activate an enzyme that takes away the flavor of mustard. Grind the mustard seed if it is not already ground. You can use a mortar and pestle if you have one, or a cleaned-out coffee grinder, or even a blender. The sound of the grinding will change when the mustard reaches an evenly ground consistency. Pour the mustard into a dish and mix with liquid until it is about the consistency of a thick ketchup. For a quick, hot mustard that you will use right away, use water; otherwise use wine/beer/mead, vinegar, or grape juice. Feel free to combine liquids. Add any desired sweeteners, such as honey, sugar, artificial sweetener, ground dates or raisins, to taste.  Add ground spices. To make it sweeter, try anise or cinnamon; to make it hotter, try ginger, cloves, horseradish (as is the norm in Europe), or one of the black peppers. Taste and adjust seasoning. Mix together, cover, and leave on the counter until the hotness is at your desired strength. Heat and bitterness will reach a peak in 5-15 minutes; water-based mustard should be served then. For other kinds of mustard, wait between 2 hours and a day for flavors to blend. Aging for a day is typically needed for the flavors to mellow, however some find that the best flavor arises after aging for several weeks. Aging mustard in the refrigerator will cause it to stay hotter longer. Aging mustard in a closed container in a cupboard or on the counter is generally considered safe, as mustard has anti-bacterial properties. Adjust consistency as necessary with juice, vinegar, or other liquids; mustard will thicken over time.  Alternative Method Take the dry ingredients. Grind in a spice grinder until relatively fine. This way you won't have to do any soaking. Add the liquid ingredients to a glass bowl.  Add the dry to the liquid and mix  well with a fork.  Microwave on high for 1 minute.  Mix well with a stick blender until creamy.  Let the mixture rest. It will thicken as it cools. Finished.
